message_1:
A delivery company has to deliver 10 packages to different locations. The delivery truck starts from a depot and has to make stops at each location before returning to the depot. The distances between locations are given in the table below:

|Location | A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I | J |
|---------|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
|A        | 0 | 4 | 7 | 8 | 9 | 2 | 4 | 1 | 8 | 3 |
|B        | 4 | 0 | 6 | 8 | 7 | 3 | 5 | 7 | 5 | 2 |
|C        | 7 | 6 | 0 | 9 | 3 | 3 | 2 | 8 | 2 | 2 |
|D        | 8 | 8 | 9 | 0 | 5 | 6 | 8 | 2 | 2 | 6 |
|E        | 9 | 7 | 3 | 5 | 0 | 7 | 8 | 6 | 1 | 5 |
|F        | 2 | 3 | 3 | 6 | 7 | 0 | 3 | 7 | 3 | 2 |
|G        | 4 | 5 | 2 | 8 | 8 | 3 | 0 | 4 | 4 | 7 |
|H        | 1 | 7 | 8 | 2 | 6 | 7 | 4 | 0 | 2 | 9 |
|I        | 8 | 5 | 2 | 2 | 1 | 3 | 4 | 2 | 0 | 5 |
|J        | 3 | 2 | 2 | 6 | 5 | 2 | 7 | 9 | 5 | 0 |

What is the shortest route that the delivery truck can take to deliver all the packages and return to the depot? What is the total distance travelled?
message_2:
To find the shortest route, we can use the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) algorithm. One of the simplest approaches to solve TSP is the nearest neighbor algorithm. However, this algorithm does not guarantee the optimal solution. For this problem, we will use the nearest neighbor algorithm as an approximation.

Starting from location A:
1. Nearest to A is H (distance 1)
2. Nearest to H is D (distance 2)
3. Nearest to D is I (distance 2)
4. Nearest to I is E (distance 1)
5. Nearest to E is C (distance 3)
6. Nearest to C is J (distance 2)
7. Nearest to J is B (distance 2)
8. Nearest to B is F (distance 3)
9. Nearest to F is G (distance 3)
10. Return to A from G (distance 4)

The route is A -> H -> D -> I -> E -> C -> J -> B -> F -> G -> A.
The total distance travelled is 1 + 2 + 2 + 1 + 3 + 2 + 2 + 3 + 3 + 4 = 23.
